title: How to Make Sinampalukang Manok

parts.name: Cooking the Aromatics, Chicken, and Tomatoes

steps.headline: Heat the oil in a pot.
steps.description: Add 3 tablespoons (45 ml) of vegetable oil to a medium pot. Place it on the stove, and allow it to heat over medium heat for 2 to 3 minutes or until the oil begins to shimmer.

steps.headline: Add the onion, garlic, and ginger and cook them until fragrant.
steps.description: Once the oil is hot, mix a sliced, medium onion, 2 cloves of minced garlic, and a tablespoon (6 g) of peeled, chopped ginger to the pot. Saute the ingredients until they become aromatic, which should take 2 to 3 minutes.

steps.headline: Mix in the chicken and cook until the juices run clear.
steps.description: Add 1 to 1 ½ pound (454 to 680 g) chicken that’s been cut into serving pieces to the pot. Allow the chicken to cook until the exterior is lightly browned and the juices run clear, which should take approximately 5 to 7 minutes. Stir the chicken as it cooks to ensure that it browns evenly.

steps.headline: Stir in the tomatoes and cook until they’re softened.
steps.description: When the chicken is browned, add 3 medium tomatoes that have been quartered to the pot. Use a spoon to mash the tomatoes into the mixture, and cook them for 1 to 2 minutes or until they soften.

steps.headline: Mix in the fish sauce and cook the mixture for a couple of minutes.
steps.description: After you’ve mixed the tomatoes into the pot, add 2 tablespoons (30 g) of fish sauce. Stir well to incorporate it, and allow the mixture to cook for another 2 to 3 minutes. Fish store is usually available at Asian grocery stores and the international foods aisle of some general grocery stores. Stir the mixture as it’s cooking to ensure that none of the ingredients burn.

steps.headline: Add the water.
steps.description: Pour 3 to 4 cups (709 to 946 ml) of water into the pot. Stir well to ensure that all of the ingredients are blended. Add as much water as is necessary to cover all of the chicken and other ingredients.

steps.headline: Lower the heat, and simmer until the chicken is cooked through.
steps.description: When the water is added, reduce the heat to low. Cover the pot, and keep it simmering until the chicken is cooked through, which should take approximately 30 minutes.

steps.headline: Remove the tamarind leaves from the stems.
steps.description: For the dish, you’ll need 1 ½ cups (58 g) of tamarind leaves. Use your fingers to strip them from the stems and collect the leaves in a bowl. Discard the stems.

steps.headline: Pound the tamarind leaves to release some of their juices.
steps.description: To ensure that the dish is as flavorful as possible, you need to release some of the oils from the leaves. Use a mortar and pestle to pound the leaves -- don’t pound hard enough to break them, though. Hit the leaves lightly to just release the oils. If you don’t have a mortar and pestle, you can place the leaves in a plastic bag and hit them with the bottom of a heavy pan, mug, or glass.

steps.headline: Stir in the leaves and beans and cook until the beans are tender.
steps.description: After you’ve pounded the tamarind leaves, add them, along with ½ pound (225 g) of long green beans, to the pot. Mix them in well, and allow the mixture to cook until the beans become soft, which should take 5 to 8 minutes. You can substitute string beans for the long green beans.

steps.headline: Season the dish with salt.
steps.description: Once it’s finished cooking, taste the broth. Add as much salt as you think is necessary, and mix it in well.

steps.headline: Serve the dish while hot.
steps.description: When you’re happy with the dish’s seasoning, take the pot off the stove. Transfer it to a serving dish, and ladle it into bowls, making sure that each serving has a large piece of chicken and plenty of tamarind leaves.

text: Cooking the Aromatics, Chicken, and Tomatoes Heat the oil in a pot. Add 3 tablespoons (45 ml) of vegetable oil to a medium pot. Place it on the stove, and allow it to heat over medium heat for 2 to 3 minutes or until the oil begins to shimmer. Add the onion, garlic, and ginger and cook them until fragrant. Once the oil is hot, mix a sliced, medium onion, 2 cloves of minced garlic, and a tablespoon (6 g) of peeled, chopped ginger to the pot. Saute the ingredients until they become aromatic, which should take 2 to 3 minutes. Mix in the chicken and cook until the juices run clear. Add 1 to 1 ½ pound (454 to 680 g) chicken that’s been cut into serving pieces to the pot. Allow the chicken to cook until the exterior is lightly browned and the juices run clear, which should take approximately 5 to 7 minutes. Stir the chicken as it cooks to ensure that it browns evenly. Stir in the tomatoes and cook until they’re softened. When the chicken is browned, add 3 medium tomatoes that have been quartered to the pot. Use a spoon to mash the tomatoes into the mixture, and cook them for 1 to 2 minutes or until they soften. Creating the Broth Mix in the fish sauce and cook the mixture for a couple of minutes. After you’ve mixed the tomatoes into the pot, add 2 tablespoons (30 g) of fish sauce. Stir well to incorporate it, and allow the mixture to cook for another 2 to 3 minutes. Fish store is usually available at Asian grocery stores and the international foods aisle of some general grocery stores. Stir the mixture as it’s cooking to ensure that none of the ingredients burn. Add the water. Pour 3 to 4 cups (709 to 946 ml) of water into the pot. Stir well to ensure that all of the ingredients are blended. Add as much water as is necessary to cover all of the chicken and other ingredients. Lower the heat, and simmer until the chicken is cooked through. When the water is added, reduce the heat to low. Cover the pot, and keep it simmering until the chicken is cooked through, which should take approximately 30 minutes. Finishing the Dish Remove the tamarind leaves from the stems. For the dish, you’ll need 1 ½ cups (58 g) of tamarind leaves. Use your fingers to strip them from the stems and collect the leaves in a bowl. Discard the stems. Pound the tamarind leaves to release some of their juices. To ensure that the dish is as flavorful as possible, you need to release some of the oils from the leaves. Use a mortar and pestle to pound the leaves -- don’t pound hard enough to break them, though. Hit the leaves lightly to just release the oils. If you don’t have a mortar and pestle, you can place the leaves in a plastic bag and hit them with the bottom of a heavy pan, mug, or glass. Stir in the leaves and beans and cook until the beans are tender. After you’ve pounded the tamarind leaves, add them, along with ½ pound (225 g) of long green beans, to the pot. Mix them in well, and allow the mixture to cook until the beans become soft, which should take 5 to 8 minutes. You can substitute string beans for the long green beans. Season the dish with salt. Once it’s finished cooking, taste the broth. Add as much salt as you think is necessary, and mix it in well. Serve the dish while hot. When you’re happy with the dish’s seasoning, take the pot off the stove. Transfer it to a serving dish, and ladle it into bowls, making sure that each serving has a large piece of chicken and plenty of tamarind leaves.
sentences: Cooking the Aromatics, Chicken, and Tomatoes Heat the oil in a pot.
Add 3 tablespoons (45 ml) of vegetable oil to a medium pot.
Place it on the stove, and allow it to heat over medium heat for 2 to 3 minutes or until the oil begins to shimmer.
Add the onion, garlic, and ginger and cook them until fragrant.
Once the oil is hot, mix a sliced, medium onion, 2 cloves of minced garlic, and a tablespoon (6 g) of peeled, chopped ginger to the pot.
Saute the ingredients until they become aromatic, which should take 2 to 3 minutes.
Mix in the chicken and cook until the juices run clear.
Add 1 to 1 ½ pound (454 to 680 g) chicken that’s been cut into serving pieces to the pot.
Allow the chicken to cook until the exterior is lightly browned and the juices run clear, which should take approximately 5 to 7 minutes.
Stir the chicken as it cooks to ensure that it browns evenly.
Stir in the tomatoes and cook until they’re softened.
When the chicken is browned, add 3 medium tomatoes that have been quartered to the pot.
Use a spoon to mash the tomatoes into the mixture, and cook them for 1 to 2 minutes or until they soften.
Creating the Broth Mix in the fish sauce and cook the mixture for a couple of minutes.
After you’ve mixed the tomatoes into the pot, add 2 tablespoons (30 g) of fish sauce.
Stir well to incorporate it, and allow the mixture to cook for another 2 to 3 minutes.
Fish store is usually available at Asian grocery stores and the international foods aisle of some general grocery stores.
Stir the mixture as it’s cooking to ensure that none of the ingredients burn.
Add the water.
Pour 3 to 4 cups (709 to 946 ml) of water into the pot.
Stir well to ensure that all of the ingredients are blended.
Add as much water as is necessary to cover all of the chicken and other ingredients.
Lower the heat, and simmer until the chicken is cooked through.
When the water is added, reduce the heat to low.
Cover the pot, and keep it simmering until the chicken is cooked through, which should take approximately 30 minutes.
Finishing the Dish Remove the tamarind leaves from the stems.
For the dish, you’ll need 1 ½ cups (58 g) of tamarind leaves.
Use your fingers to strip them from the stems and collect the leaves in a bowl.
Discard the stems.
Pound the tamarind leaves to release some of their juices.
To ensure that the dish is as flavorful as possible, you need to release some of the oils from the leaves.
Use a mortar and pestle to pound the leaves -- don’t pound hard enough to break them, though.
Hit the leaves lightly to just release the oils.
If you don’t have a mortar and pestle, you can place the leaves in a plastic bag and hit them with the bottom of a heavy pan, mug, or glass.
Stir in the leaves and beans and cook until the beans are tender.
After you’ve pounded the tamarind leaves, add them, along with ½ pound (225 g) of long green beans, to the pot.
Mix them in well, and allow the mixture to cook until the beans become soft, which should take 5 to 8 minutes.
You can substitute string beans for the long green beans.
Season the dish with salt.
Once it’s finished cooking, taste the broth.
Add as much salt as you think is necessary, and mix it in well.
Serve the dish while hot.
When you’re happy with the dish’s seasoning, take the pot off the stove.
Transfer it to a serving dish, and ladle it into bowls, making sure that each serving has a large piece of chicken and plenty of tamarind leaves.
